The patient’s laboratory studies suggest Goodpasture syndrome, which is characterized by anti-GBM antibodies, pulmonary hemorrhage, and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Treatment typically includes corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide, but plasmapheresis is also needed to remove the circulating antibodies. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to perform plasmapheresis. Administering fluticasone, hemodialysis, and enalapril are not indicated for Goodpasture syndrome.

The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest Goodpasture syndrome, which is characterized by anti-GBM antibodies and renal and pulmonary involvement. Cyclophosphamide and prednisone are appropriate initial treatments. Plasmapheresis is recommended in addition to immunosuppressive therapy in cases of severe disease or in those who fail to respond to initial treatment. Hemodialysis may be necessary for patients with severe renal failure, but it is not the appropriate initial next step. Administering fluticasone or enalapril would not address the underlying disease process.

The patient needs urgent plasmapheresis to remove the circulating antibodies from the blood. Prednisone and cyclophosphamide are used to suppress the immune system, and inhalative fluticasone is not indicated in this case. Hemodialysis may be necessary in severe cases of kidney failure, but it is not the first-line treatment. Enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that may be used to control blood pressure, but it does not address the underlying autoimmune disorder.
